results.title: Razorback
results.creator_credit: Hal McElroy, UAA Films, Western and Russell Mulcahy
results.brief_description: Story of a female animal rights campaigner who vanishes in the outback. Her husband sets out to find her, coming up against a monstrous wild boar that’s terrorising the countryside. Stars Gregory Harrison and Arkie Whiteley with Bill Kerr, Chris Haywood and Judy Morris.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hal McElroy, UAA Films, Western and Russell Mulcahy
results.description:
Pitched as ‘Jaws on trotters’, this creature feature rises above its B-grade premise of a killer pig thanks to American ex-pat screenwriter Everett De Roche’s script and Russel Mulcahy’s distinct, music video style.

When a movie opens with world-weary grandfather Jake (Bill Kerr) putting his grandson to bed only to have the pig burst into the house and drag the child off into the night, you know you’re in for a trip. With shades of the Lindy Chamberlain case, Jake goes to trial but is acquitted for the child’s death. In the community’s eyes, he remains suspicious. While he searches for the boar that gorged his grandson, American traveller Carl (Gregory Harrison) searches for his missing girlfriend, a wildlife reporter who’s met a grisly fate at both the hands of a man and tusks of the eponymous pig.

While the storyline may not be the most sophisticated, the film is lauded for its visual flare and uncanny environment. As The New York Times notes, “the landscapes… have a wonderfully bizarre, almost Dali-esque character. This is a place where the full moon never wanes…”

Likewise, the limitations imposed by the quality of the animatronic boar also inform the optic amazement. Though it cost $250,000 to make, Razorback doesn’t look that great, so Mulcahy treats the creature much like Spielberg does his great white – it’s rarely seen.

The Guardian’s Luke Buckmaster considers the limitation a boon. “The director took on the challenge with gusto, creating a berserk aesthetic infused with POV shots, busy backgrounds, images graded with extreme colour and shadows and mega close-ups of the creature’s tusks and mouth. Razorback is a work of gut-busting visual bravado.”

Not bad praise for the man who directed Bonnie Tyler’s ‘Total Eclipse of the Heart’.

Rusell Mulcahy also holds the honour of being the director of the first video clip to ever appear on MTV.

results.title: Rays from atoms
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Atomic physics: an historical approach”.
A five part series designed for use in the science departments of universities, technical colleges, and schools teaching advanced physics, tracing the development of atomic energy from the days when John Dalton put forward his atomic theory in 1808, until the present day. This episode (part 2) deals with the development of X-rays and cathode rays.

results.title: Raymonda
results.creator_credit: Takeshi Hara, NHK Entapuraizu, Videofilm, Bolshoi Theatre of the USSR, RPTA, Primetime and Shuji Fujii
results.brief_description: The Bolshoi Theatre Ballet performs Raymonda at the Bolshoi Theatre, music by Aleksandr Glazunov, scenario by Lydia Pashkova and Marius Petipa with original choreography by Marius Petipa and Aleksandr Gorsky, revised by Yuri Grigorovich. Raymonda (Natalya Bessmertnova) is to marry Jean de Brienne (Yuri Vasyuchenko), but the Saraceb knight, Abderakhman (Gediminas Taranda), forces his attention on her while her betrothed is on a crusade. At the last moment Jean returns, fights his rival and wins the hand of Raymonda. With a spectacular stage setting and costume design, powerful performances by the principal dancers, and the magical sound of the music of the Bolshoi Theatre Orchestra conducted by Algis Zhuraitis.

results.title: Raymond Loewy: father of industrial design
results.creator_credit: Suzanne St Pierre, CBS News and 60 Minutes
results.brief_description: Raymond Loewy’s streamlined functionalism has set the standards in modern industrial design for 70 years. Loewy animatedly discusses the elements of good design, and strolls through a hardware store finding ineffectively designed items among the store’s wares. At 85 he is as sharp as ever, and still working to improve the most ordinary object. Includes his personal philosophy on the function of the designer.

results.title: Raymond Klibansky: from philosophy to life
results.creator_credit: Yves Bisaillon, ONF | NFB, Tele-Quebec and Anne-Marie Tougas
results.brief_description: This beautifully filmed portrayal of German Jewish philosopher Raymond Klibansky by director Anne-Marie Tougas resulted from a meeting Tougas had with the great philosopher and the profound effect Klibansky had on her during that meeting. Inspired by Klibansky, Tougas has written a script, poetic in tone and atmospheric in mood, which transforms this documentary into a thoughtful and at moments, even sensual, piece of work. Born in 1905, Klibansky has spanned a century of change, of war, oppression, upheaval, peace and liberation. A historian and philosopher, he is also a political activist and a strong believer in humanism and tolerance. Between World War I and II, he moved to Heidelberg, Germany, a vibrant and intellectual city where, as a professor at Heidelberg University, he mixed with the academia, sociologists and other philosophers. With the rise of Hitler and nazism Klibansky went into exile in England where he became Chief Intelligence Officer in the British Secret Service during World War II. In 1946 he finally moved to Montreal where he has continued to promote tolerance and fight for freedom on all fronts. Klibansky discusses his life, analyses his philosophy and its relationship to world events and humanity and provides perhaps a different slant on world history during the 20th century. Included in the documentary are stills, photographs, archival newsreel footage and interviews with Sonja Sutton-Steiniger (Klibansky’s sister), Ethel Groffier (his wife), Georges Leroux (philosopher and friend), Rainer Maria Lepsius (sociologist), Jana Patocka (daughter of philosopher Jan Patocka) among others. Voice and narration by Claudio Besso in English with some interviews in French with English subtitles.
